title: Virtue Ethics: Not Practically Useful, Either
summary:
Key Ideas:
- The problem of "doing the right thing" consists of two sub-problems.
- Virtue ethics is a uniquely excellent solution to the second sub-problem.
- The author's experience of morality is largely not in line with traditional virtue ethics.
- Virtue ethics is not an effective way to make people more moral.
- There are many other beliefs and practices that are more likely to work than adopting virtue ethics.

Key Learnings:
- Virtue ethics does not claim to be a solution to the first problem of "doing the right thing."
- Virtue ethics is not an effective way to make people more moral.
- There are many other beliefs and practices that are more likely to work than adopting virtue ethics.

Key Questions:
- Is virtue ethics an effective solution to the problem of "doing the right thing"?
- How does the author's experience of morality differ from traditional virtue ethics?
- What other beliefs and practices are more effective than virtue ethics in making people more moral?
